question: In a 2-out-of-5 code, if the probability of an error occurring in a single position is \( p \) and the probability of no error is \( q = 1 - p \), calculate the probability of exactly one error occurring in the code.
solution:
The probability of exactly one error occurring in a 2-out-of-5 code can be calculated using the binomial coefficient:

\[
P(\text{1 error}) = C(5, 1) p q^4
\]

Calculating \( C(5, 1) \):

\[
C(5, 1) = 5
\]

Thus, the probability becomes:

\[
P(\text{1 error}) = 5 p (1 - p)^4
\]

Therefore, the probability of exactly one error occurring is 

\[
\boxed{5p(1 - p)^4}
\]
